docs.snippet: Danfung Dennis's documentary is filled with intimate moments that fictional war films like "Act of Valor" could never accomplish. "To Hell and Back Again" concerns the immediate action of war, which in real life happens in unexpected, violent burs...
docs.abstract: Danfung Dennis's documentary is filled with intimate moments that fictional war films like "Act of Valor" could never accomplish. "To Hell and Back Again" concerns the immediate action of war, which in real life happens in unexpected, violent bursts of seconds or minutes.

headline.main: 'Hell and Back Again' Shows War Stories Don't End When War Movies Do

docs.snippet: On the Carpetbagger blog at carpetbagger.blogs.nytimes.com, we asked readers how they would fix the Oscars. Here are excerpts from their comments:     My suggestion to the Academy: Bar for life any actor who serves as a presenter on the Golden Goo...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the Carpetbagger blog at carpetbagger.blogs.nytimes.com, we asked readers how they would fix the Oscars. Here are excerpts from their comments: My suggestion to the Academy: Bar for life any actor who serves as a presenter on the Golden Goose-eggs, the Saggies, etc., from participating in the same capacity on Oscar night. Without big-name presenters those ceremonies will quickly fade into obscurity. As for making the voting membership younger: Anyone who hasn't made a theatrical film in over 10 years should be considered ''inactive'' and, hence, ineligible to vote. Also, why not rename the trophy ''the Harvey''? Stu FreemanBrooklyn
docs.abstract: Excerpts from readers' comments on the Carpetbagger blog on ways to make the Oscars more appealing. (M)0

headline.main: Shorter Gowns, or Maybe Just Better Films
